dosing_protocols.context: Pulsed weekly dosing to achieve mTORC1 inhibition while allowing immune recovery between doses. For adults over 40 with no active infections or wound healing needs.

peer_reviewed_citations.citation: Mannick JB, Del Giudice G, Lattanzi M, et al. (2014) mTOR inhibition improves immune function in the elderly. Science Translational Medicine. 6(268):268ra179
peer_reviewed_citations.relevance: Supports intermittent mTOR inhibition concept; studied RAD001 weekly dosing

peer_reviewed_citations.citation: Harrison DE, Strong R, Sharp ZD, et al. (2009) Rapamycin fed late in life extends lifespan in genetically heterogeneous mice. Nature. 460(7253):392-395
peer_reviewed_citations.relevance: ITP study demonstrating rapamycin lifespan extension in mice

dosing_protocols.context: For adults over 50 with robust health status. Some practitioners prefer 6mg for more robust effect.
Standard transplant dosing per FDA labeling. Requires therapeutic drug monitoring.

mechanism_claims.specificity: mTORC1 selective at low/pulsed doses; mTORC2 inhibition at higher continuous doses
mechanism_claims.context: Rapamycin binds FKBP12, forming complex that directly inhibits mTORC1. Weekly pulsed dosing preferentially inhibits mTORC1 while allowing mTORC2 recovery.

peer_reviewed_citations.citation: Sarbassov DD, Ali SM, Sengupta S, et al. (2006) Prolonged rapamycin treatment inhibits mTORC2 assembly and Akt/PKB. Mol Cell. 22(2):159-168
peer_reviewed_citations.relevance: Demonstrates differential mTORC1/mTORC2 sensitivity to rapamycin

mechanism_claims.context: mTORC1 inhibition relieves suppression of ULK1, activating autophagy machinery

peer_reviewed_citations.citation: Kim J, Kundu M, Bhavani V, et al. (2011) AMPK and mTOR regulate autophagy through direct phosphorylation of Ulk1. Nat Cell Biol. 13(2):132-141

mechanism_claims.context: Acute mTORC1 inhibition reduces PGC-1alpha transcriptional activity
Chronic rapamycin may upregulate PGC-1alpha through enhanced mitophagy and compensatory mitochondrial biogenesis

regulatory_status.fda: Approved for transplant rejection prophylaxis; off-label for longevity
regulatory_status.notes: Prescription required. Off-label longevity use not FDA-endorsed.

monitoring: Drug levels if using for transplant

interactions.recommendation: Avoid or adjust dose; monitor levels

position_a.detail: Most commonly cited dose in longevity protocols

position_b.summary: 6mg weekly for adults over 50 with robust health
position_b.detail: Some practitioners prefer slightly higher dose for more robust effect

conflicts.characterization: Both doses are within a reasonable range for longevity protocols. The difference may reflect patient population (more robust patients may tolerate/benefit from 6mg) or practitioner preference. Neither is definitively 'correct.'
conflicts.clinical_note: Consider starting at 5mg and adjusting based on response and tolerability. Either dose is reasonable for longevity protocols in otherwise healthy adults.

position_a.detail: Acute mTORC1 inhibition reduces PGC-1alpha transcriptional activity

position_b.detail: Long-term use enhances mitophagy leading to compensatory mitochondrial biogenesis

conflicts.characterization: These positions likely describe different timeframes of rapamycin's effect. Acutely, mTORC1 inhibition directly suppresses PGC-1alpha. Chronically, enhanced autophagy/mitophagy may trigger compensatory mitochondrial biogenesis. Both mechanisms are biologically plausible.
conflicts.clinical_note: When evaluating rapamycin's effect on mitochondrial biogenesis, consider treatment duration. Short-term vs long-term use may show different effects on PGC-1alpha and mitochondrial outcomes.
